Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support a group of four highly experienced PI's to work on the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, the European particle physics laboratory. The LHC machine and ATLAS detector were built using funds from the NSF and from other agencies around the world. It proved its worth three years ago when scientists discovered the Higgs Boson, the last particle in the historically successful "Standard Model" (SM) that accounts for so much of the known matter in the universe. In spite of its success, the Standard Model still leaves a number of questions about the fundamental structure of the universe unanswered, giving rise to research exploring Beyond the Standard Model (BSM). This award will allow the PI's to continue their leading role in studies of the Higgs width and couplings, properties that have so far established it as the SM object anticipated. It will also support their continuing search for BSM that could materialize at the higher energy experiments that are currently underway.

The group supports a vigorous broader impact program. The centerpiece of this is a large, modular, multi-panel exhibit of ATLAS and the LHC. This has been used at major science festivals in NYC and Washington DC, and will be sent to other festivals around the country. They also plan to continue their leadership role in the ATLAS Zooniverse project, which allows the public to view and analyze ATLAS events.

This project will be leveraged by the group's expertise in the operations of the ATLAS trigger, responsible for selection of the interesting reactions that occur in ATLAS. This becomes increasingly key to the physics potential of the LHC in Run2. In this run the LHC will operate at 13 TeV, almost double its currently highest energy of 8 TeV. In addition to conventional approaches to the trigger, and to enhancing sensitivity to new physics, the group will attempt prototyping new strategies such as "data scouting" that can fill holes in traditional off-line data analysis pipelines. They will also work on including the transverse momentum trigger, the trigger menu, trigger software, statistical methods and tools, analysis tools, pileup simulation techniques, and event visualization tools. They also plan detailed study of silicon detector properties using the infrastructure they have developed for the ATLAS upgrade.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported the work of our NYU group's research into fundamental particle physics at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) located at CERN. The goal of particle physics is to understand the nature of the elementary constituents of matter and the forces that govern their interactions. Such understanding is foundational and can, in turn, teach us about a wide variety of phenomena including the development of the Universe itself after the Big Bang. The experimental effort at the LHC involves enormous technical challenges and a tremendous amount of data, which makes this research an excellent training ground for future physicist and those entering the workforce.

Our group used the data from the LHC to search for evidence of physics beyond the Standard Model (SM), which is the currently accepted theory of fundamental particles. While the SM has been enormously successful, we know that it is incomplete.  Astrophysical evidence of dark matter, the masses of neutrinos, and the mass of the Higgs boson all point to something Beyond the Standard Model (BSM). As experimental physicists our goal is to create the most stringent tests of the SM in hopes of uncovering BSM physics. This comes in the form of searches for new particles and forces as well as precise measurements of quantities predicted by the SM. 

The NYU group is a member of the ATLAS experiment at the LHC and also involved in the milliQan, a small experiment searching for an exotic type of matter with a very small electric charge. Within the ATLAS experiment, the group has performed a number of searches for particles predicted by BSM theories and performed precise measurements. The group has developed novel methodology that uses machine learning and statistics to enhance the power of these searches and measurements. The group has also developed technologies that allow the experiment to preserve those analyses for later reuse. This aids in reinterpreting searches to test new BSM theories and streamlines the onboarding of new researchers into the LHC experiments. The group has also made important contributions to the simulation of interactions at the LHC, which is the way in which the predictions of SM and BSM theories are realized. Additionally, the group has had sustained responsibilities in the trigger system, which processes 40 million collisions per second to decide in real time which of these collisions should be saved for subsequent scrutiny.

We have also worked to ensure the work supported by this award has broader impacts. The NYU group has established strong connections with the community developing modern data science and machine learning techniques, and is widely recognized in this space. This interaction not only improves the techniques being used to analyze the LHC data, but also enhances the development of the workforce.

In collaboration with Brookhaven National Laboratory we have developed and held a workshop on statistical methods with the ATLAS trigger as a starting point then leading to a broader discussion of how statistics can be used or misused in deriving conclusions based on data. Our LHC exhibit has been shown in several large venues and brought the excitement of this science to the general public. Our group co-leads the HiggsHunters citizen science project as part of Zooniverse, which has allowed more than 50,000 volunteers worldwide to learn more about particle physics and participate in scientific research.
